Up in the balcony, over the seats, are the holes of the projection booth. The middle camouflaged by the huge head of a roaring lion, all in pl lens of the projector can be glimpsed between its sharp t there are two smaller holes, through which the figure of made out, appearing and disappearing...It is ALFREDO, the projectionist. He is around forty, skinny and bony with a peasant face. He has finished loading the projector and i carbons in the arc lamp. OK, Alfredo, you can start!! He sits down an by himself in the middle of the empty the Up in the booth, ALFREDO lights the arc lamp and sets the projector going. Down in the theatre, the light goes off and out of the li streams the glowing ray aimed al the screen. String music and ominous, spreads through the theatre. On the screen a the credit titles of an American film of the 1940s. The P screws up his face and holds the bell in his right hand r the arm of his seat. At the back of the theatre, behind the last row, a curtai opens a crack and SALVATORE'S gaunt little face appears. has managed to sneak in somehow and stands there without word, spellbound, watching the 'movie' on the glowing scr The credit titles have long come and gone. The story is a turning-point.  Up above, in the hole of the booth next to the lion, ALFREDO watches the film, but his eyes keep looking down PRIEST, who is now drumming the bell with his fingers. On screen, the male and female lead, two Hollywood stars, ar close-up; the dialogue is passionate, romantic. SALVATORE carried away by those faces, by the way they talk, by the of the woman, slowly slips down the length of the curtain is sitting on the floor, his eyes glued to the screen.  The love scene reaches a climax, the music crescendos, an couple finally fall into each other's arms and kiss. Inst raises the bell into the air, as in some age-old ceremony ring... Up in the booth ALFREDO hears the bell; it's the signal h waiting for. He takes a slip of paper from a pad prepared purpose and sticks it into the loops of the film containi specific scene as it winds on to the reel. The projection continues... ...And also the kiss of the two actors. The PRIEST'S nerv those black-and-white lips meeting and now pulling apart declaration of love before separating. SALVATORE is wide- never seen a man and woman kiss before, it's a vision tha attraction of forbidden fruit, the horror of sin. The scr the figure of a woman getting undressed, showing for one voluptuous flesh of her broad, naked shoulders. SALVATORE wonder. The PRIEST, in a fury, grabs the bell and shakes From the sound of the bell to another sound...

The tolling of the bell-tower rings out over the  square. It is noon. head_text.subj: SQUARE AND ENTRANCE OF CINEMA PARADISO. EXT. NIGHT

Thanks, Uncle Alfredo. Thanks. Good- night. She walks away, dragging SALVATORE by the hand. ALFREDO gives him a wink. (Breathless)

Of course I knew your father. He was  tall, thin, pleasant, and had a  moustache like mine. Always smiling.  He looked like Clark Gable.  There's something SALVATORE wants to talk about, but he d start. He has a try with an innocent stratagem.

ALFREDO knows exactly what the little rascal is up to, an strange, theatrical tone, as if he were repeating somethi remark taken from some old film.
'I choose my friends for their
looks, and my enemies for their  brains...'  (Laughs)

All right, all right! When I've got  kids that's what I'm telling them!  (The outlying houses of  Giancaldo finally heave  into sight.)

(Cowed)

And who gave him all those films?  Promise you won't give him any more  of this trash! Don't let him set foot  any more in the movie house. The  boy's crazy! Crazy! All he talks  about is movies and Alfredo' Alfredo  and movies!!  ALFREDO is crestfallen, didn't think that SALVATORE'S cra passion for movies, could go this far.

It's not true! No! It's not true!!!  I'll show you he's coming back! And she beats him desperately, as if to enforce her stubb slap. This time ALFREDO doesn't step in, lets MARIA give to her rage and fury, but SALVATORE'S cries make him feel

No...It's nothing to do with you.  It's just that I was scared of coming  back. Now, after all these years, I  thought I was strong, that I had  forgotten lots of things. Instead, I  find it's quite the opposite, as if I  had never left. And yet, I look at  Lia and feel as if I didn't know her,  and you, Mamma...I abandoned you,  ran away like a thief, thought only  of myself, and never gave you  an explanation...
(Interrupting him)
And I never asked for one! You have  nothing to explain. I always thought  that what you did was right, and that  was that. With no beating around the  bush... (Smiling, playing it down)
Only one thing made me suffer:  bolting the door shut before going to  bed at night...
You never used to do that!  She smiles like a little girl who is about to confess the

No, no...When you used to work at  the movies, I could never get to  sleep at night until you came home.  Then when you arrived, I pretended to  be asleep, but I heard all your  movements. Then when you fell asleep,  I'd get up and bolt the door. Then,  when you left, every time I did it, I  felt as if I had left somebody  outside the door, far away....  (SALVATORE listens to his  MOTHER'S words, surprised  and entranced by the  poetry of her way of  speaking...)
But you were right to leave. You  succeeded in doing what you wanted to  do... (Sighing)
When I call you, a different, woman  always answers. I pretend I know them  so they won't have to go through the  embarrassment of introducing  themselves.  (Smiling)

I'm sure they take me for a crazy old  woman. But so far I've never heard  one voice that really loves you...I  would have known. And yet, I'd like  to see you...settled down...fall in  love... (Gazing into his eyes)

But your life's there. Here there are  nothing but ghosts, Toto! Let it go.  She has said this with a subtle allusiveness in her voice realizes she has always known everything.
